metadata.title: Efficient catalytic upcycling of polyester and polycarbonate plastics using an NNN-based iron catalyst

Scheme 1 Hydrogenative depolymerization of polyester and polycarbonate plastics. a Previous work on polyesters hydrogenolysis by homogeneous catalysts. b The present work on catalytic methanolysis/transfer hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis of polyesters and polycarbonate using an iron pincer catalyst. Scheme 2 The synthesis of [Fe(NNHN)Cl2]2. Scheme 3 Catalytic transfer hydrogenation of esters using Fe1. Reaction conditions: substrate (1.0 mmol), H3N·BH3 (1.0 mmol), Fe1 (0.02 mmol), KO t Bu (0.05 mmol), THF (2 mL), 60 °C, and 12 h and isolated yields are given. Scheme 4 Catalytic methanolysis/hydrogenative depolymerization of polyester and polycarbonate plastics. Scheme 5 Deuterated experiment for methanolysis of PET. Scheme 6 Hydrogenolysis of selected polyesters and polycarbonate consumer products. Efficient catalytic upcycling of polyester and polycarbonate plastics using an NNN-based iron catalyst Xiaoxiao Chu Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization a Guoren Zhou Writing – original draft Software Investigation a Chongyan Ren Validation Investigation Formal analysis a Xiaoshi Zhang Writing – review & editing Resources b Maofu Pang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Investigation Funding acquisition a ⁎ Nuoyan Zhao Investigation a Hongwu Zhang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Ludong University, Yantai 264025, PR China School of Chemistry and Materials Science Ludong University Yantai 264025 PR China School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Ludong University, Yantai 264025, PR China b School of Engineering, Penn State Behrend, Erie, PA 16563, United States School of Engineering Penn State Behrend Erie PA 16563 United States School of Engineering, Penn State Behrend, Erie, PA 16563, United States ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract This study introduces an iron-based pincer catalyst that efficiently hydrogenolysis polyesters and polycarbonates into valuable diols using different methods. The phosphine-free catalyst demonstrates high activity and selectivity, achieving excellent yields for PET, PBT, PCL, PLA, and PC. The development of efficient, eco-friendly recycling methods for mitigating the environmental impact of polyester waste remains a significant challenge. Herein, we establish an efficient catalytic system based on an NNN-based iron pincer catalyst, which can facilitate the hydrogenative depolymerization of polyester plastics using two methods. The first method is to depolymerize the polyester into ester monomers via methanolysis and facilitate subsequent transfer hydrogenation using ammonia borane as a hydrogen source to obtain diol products under mild conditions. The second method is to use molecular hydrogen as a hydrogen source for the direct catalytic hydrogenolysis of the plastic to obtain diol products. The catalyst [Fe(NNHN)Cl2] demonstrates high catalytic efficiency in the degradation of polyester and polycarbonate plastics, including when using plastic waste from daily life as raw materials. Keywords Plastic upcycling Hydrogenolysis Iron catalyst Plastic waste management Environmental sustainability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyesters are important polymeric materials extensively used in packaging, textiles, and engineering plastics [1]. Polyester plastic production significant growth and changed in recent years. In 2022, the global production of plastics reached 400.3 million metric tons, highlighting the scale of the plastic pollution problem [2]. However, plastic pollution is the world’s second largest environmental issue after climate change. Polyester plastics, due to their wide application difficult degradation, are one of the primary pollutants in soil and water [3,4]. Microplastics, especially polyester microplastics, contaminate soil, freshwater, and marine ecosystems, affecting wildlife and plant life. They can absorb and carry toxic substances, further harming the environment [5]. Marine organisms’ ingestion of microplastics can lead to bioaccumulation in the food chain, potentially affecting human health. Microplastic pollution is linked to respiratory issues and other health concerns [6]. Addressing polyester plastic pollution requires coordinated efforts from industries, governments, and consumers to adopt sustainable practices and innovative solutions. Therefore, efficient, environmentally friendly plastic recycling methods should be developed [7]. Traditional methods, such as mechanical methods, relies on the physical reprocessing of plastic waste, but with each cycle, the polymer properties progressively degrade—chain scission and loss of mechanical strength are common consequences. This limits the number of viable recycling loops and necessitates rigorous sorting and purification to avoid contamination, a process that is energy-intensive and reduces overall efficiency [8]. These limitations highlight the need for eco-friendlier approaches. The chemical recycling and upcycling of plastic waste are vital components of sustainable development [9]. These processes convert plastic waste into valuable chemicals. Compared with traditional chemical recycling methods [10,11], such as hydrolysis [12,13], methanolysis [14,15], and glycolysis [16,17], upcycling is more advantageous [18]. The recently developed transition-metals-catalyzed hydrogenative depolymerization of polyester plastic is gaining increasing attention from both industry and academia due to its high atom economy and potential to enhance sustainability and resource efficiency [19–23]. Several ruthenium pincer complexes have been utilized as catalysts for the hydrogenation depolymerization of polyester plastics with molecular hydrogen (Scheme 1 a) [24–26]. Xie et al. developed a highly efficient strategy for the hydrogenation of polyester waste that involves the initial transesterification of polyester into more degradable oligomeric fragments in the presence of CH3OH, followed by hydrogenation using a quinaldine-based Ru complex under mild conditions: 80 °C, 1 bar H2 [27]. In comparison with precious metal catalysts, Liu et al. reported the catalytic hydrogenolysis of polyester and polycarbonate polymers using a molecular NHC-based manganese pincer complex, in which a 150 °C temperature and a 50 bar H2 pressure were essential [28]. Moreover, commercially available manganese catalysts (e.g., Mn(OTf)2, Si-Mn) have also demonstrated efficient depolymerization under milder conditions [29]. Similarly, Branco and Fernandes developed a zinc-catalyzed system (Zn(OAc)2·2H2O/HBpin) that achieves excellent depolymerization yields of polyesters/polycarbonates under mild conditions, using non-toxic and inexpensive catalysts [30]. The transfer hydrogenation of polyesters and polycarbonates is less reported than hydrogenation, although it has milder reaction conditions and does not require special reaction equipment. Werner and coworkers reported the first example by using a PNP pincer-type iron complex as catalyst for the depolymerization of poly(propylene carbonate) at 140 °C with iPrOH as the hydrogen source [31]. J. G. de Vries et al. successfully depolymerized the polyester dynacol 7360 to the diol using a transfer hydrogenation protocol with EtOH on the use of the iron pincer complex Iron-MACHO-BH [32]. Additionally, Kobylarski et al. demonstrated that a lanthanum(III) tris(amide) catalyst (La[N(SiMe3)2]3) combined with hydroboranes (e.g., HBpin) could efficiently depolymerize polyesters and polycarbonates into borylated diols under mild conditions, showcasing high selectivity without over-reduction byproducts [33]. Recently, our group reported a phosphine-free Mn-NNN pincer catalyst [19] that achieved 81 % isolated yield of terephthalyl alcohol from post-consumer PET in 12 h under 20 bar H2 at 120 °C. Building on this precedent, we sought to evaluate the isostructural Fe-NNN system, motivated by the 25-fold cost advantage of FeCl2 ($7.9/g) over Mn(CO)5Br ($237.5/g) and the potential for altered mechanistic pathways arising from the lower redox potential of iron, which could translate to milder conditions or complementary substrate scope. In this work, two catalytic degradation methods are presented (Scheme 1b). The first is transfer hydrogenation with ammonia borane as the hydrogen source. The degradation reaction is divided into two steps; the first step is the methanolysis of polyester which produces plastic monomers [34,35], and the second is the transfer hydrogenation of the monomers (which produces diols). The second catalytic degradation method is direct hydrogenolysis with hydrogen as the hydrogen source, where the polyester plastic is directly degraded into diols. Both methods use the synthesized phosphine-free NNN-based iron pincer catalyst [Fe(NNHN)Cl2], which has high reactivity in methanolysis, transfer hydrogenation, or hydrogenolysis. 2 Results and discussion The pincer complexes having the NNN-ligand (dipicolyl amine) Mn(NNHN)(CO)3Br and Fe(NNHN)Br2 have been reported by Beller’s group which the former can efficiently reduce ketones to secondary alcohols with iPrOH as the hydrogen source [36] and the latter can catalyze epoxidation of linear α-Olefins with hydrogen peroxide [37]. In view of the high catalytic efficiency exhibited by the aforementioned complexes, we endeavored to synthesize a catalyst with the NNN-ligand employing FeCl2 as the metal precursor. The Fe dipicolyl amine pincer complex [Fe(NNHN)Cl2]2 (Fe1) was obtained as described. Bis(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)amine and FeCl2 were added to THF, and the mixture was heated to 50 °C and stirred for 2 h (Scheme 2 ). The suspension was recrystallized at −30 °C, and yellow microcrystals were obtained. Analysis of the crystal structure reveals that this is a dimer complex, with two chlorine atoms linking the iron center. 2.1 Catalytic transfer hydrogenation of esters In degrading plastics, such as polyethylene terephthalate (PET), we initially assessed the capability of complex Fe1 to facilitate the transfer hydrogenation of ester compounds. In initial experiments, the transfer hydrogenation of methyl benzoate was examined using 2 mol% Fe1 in conjunction with a base and H3N·BH3 as the hydrogen source (Table 1 ). Utilizing NaOH as the base at 50 °C resulted in low conversion, but the use of employing tetrahydrofuran (THF) as the solvent slightly improved this, achieving 37 % conversion (Table 1, entries 1–3). The conversion improved with NaOMe as the base (Table 1, entry 4) and increased significantly to 83 % with KO t Bu as the base (Table 1, entry 5). Elevating the reaction temperature to 60 °C further increased conversion to 96 % (Table 1, entry 6). Control experiments were conducted in the absence of Fe1 (Table 1, entry 7) or the base (Table 1, entry 8), and no conversion of methyl benzoate occurred. After the optimal conditions were established, we examined the substrate scope of the reaction using the catalyst [Fe(NNHN)Cl2]2 (Fe1). As shown in Scheme 3 , Fe1 was an efficient precatalyst for the reduction of various (hetero)aromatic and aliphatic esters. The transfer hydrogenation of 1 mmol methyl benzoate with H3N·BH3 at 60 °C in THF resulted in a 90 % isolated yield of phenylmethanol (Scheme 3, 1a). Ethyl benzoate, isopropyl benzoate, and butyl benzoate were also subjected to hydrogenation, affording phenylmethanol with high yields ranging from 85 % to 92 % under the same conditions (Scheme 3, 1b–1d). Then, the substituents were changed at the para position of the benzene ring; methyl 4-methoxybenzoate was smoothly hydrogenated, leading to an 88 % yield of (4-methoxyphenyl)methanol (Scheme 3, 1 e). The transfer hydrogenation of methyl 4-acetylbenzoate resulted in an 83 % yield of 1-(4-(hydroxymethyl)phenyl)ethan-1-ol, confirming that carbonyl groups are reducible within this catalytic system (Scheme 3, 1 f). Methyl 4-cyanobenzoate was hydrogenated to yield 75 % of 4-(hydroxymethyl)benzonitrile; this relatively low yield was ascribed to competing nitrile coordination, with the cyano group remaining intact, demonstrating the catalytic reaction's good functional group tolerance (Scheme 3, 1 g). For halogens, including fluorine and chlorine, the reaction system exhibited good compatibility, with good yields of the corresponding alcohols (Scheme 3, 1l-1p). Esters with electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups underwent transfer hydrogenation, forming the corresponding alcohols with yields ranging from good to very good. The introduction of fused-ring functional groups, such as naphthyl, into the catalytic system revealed that both methyl 1-naphthoate and methyl 2-naphthoate exhibited good reactivity, producing the corresponding alcohols (Scheme 3, 1 i and 1j). This also showed that a large steric hindrance had little effect on the reaction. The hydrogenation of [1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl benzoate resulted in [1,1′-biphenyl]-4-ol with an 83 % yield (Scheme 3, 1 k). The catalyst demonstrated robust catalytic activity for aliphatic esters; for instance, methyl pentanoate was reduced to pentan-1-ol with a 74 % yield (Scheme 3, 1 r). Similarly, methyl isobutyrate was converted into isobutanol with a 77 % yield (Scheme 3, 1 s). These low isolated yields were attributed to the volatility of the products. Methyl nonanoate was converted into nonan-1-ol with an 86 % yield (Scheme 3, 1 t). The hydrogenation of vinyl hexanoate yielded hexanol with a 75 % yield (Scheme 3, 1 u). Methyl cyclohexanecarboxylate was efficiently converted into cyclohexylmethanol with an 86 % yield (Scheme 3, 1 v). For lactone compounds, this system also facilitated efficient hydrogenation. Chroman-2-one and 5-butyldihydrofuran-2(3H)-one were successfully hydrogenated to produce 2-(3-hydroxypropyl)phenol and octane-1,4-diol with yields of 90 % and 88 %, respectively (Scheme 3, 1 q and 1w, respectively). Additionally, carbonate compounds were tested; they were efficiently converted into the corresponding alcohols with excellent isolated yields of 89 % to 93 %, indicating the broad applicability of the reaction system to carbonate substrates (Scheme 3, 1x-1z). 2.2 Catalytic methanolysis of PET The hydrogenation depolymerization of PET typically involves two sequential steps. The first step is cleaving the ester bonds within the PET via alcoholysis to produce ester monomers. The second step is hydrogenating these ester monomers to yield the corresponding diols. Given that esters have been hydrogenated and our catalytic system effectively facilitated the alcoholysis of PET, the subsequent hydrogenolysis would be feasible, resulting in the formation of diol products. We investigated the reaction conditions for PET alcoholysis and discovered that in the existing catalytic system, methanol can serve as a solvent for the methanolysis of PET (Table 2 ), yielding dimethyl terephthalate (DMT) and ethylene glycol (EG). At reaction heating temperatures not exceeding 60 °C, the separation yield of DMT was not high, with the highest isolated yield being only 71 % (Table 2, entries 1–3). When the temperature increased to 80 °C, the isolated yield reached 90 % (Table 2, entry 4). The use of alternative solvents, including tetrahydrofuran and toluene, resulted in no detectable formation of DMT (Table 2, entries 5 and 6). Reports in the literature indicate that potassium tert-butoxide can catalyze the alcoholysis of PET independently [23]; thus, we conducted a control experiment: Under identical reaction conditions, omitting the catalyst and ammonia borane resulted in an isolated yield of DMT of only 10 % (Table 2, entry 7). When the reaction temperature is elevated to 120 °C, the isolated yield of DMT reaches 39 % (Table 2, entry 9). Conversely, in the absence of potassium tert-butoxide, the reaction yield was negligible, regardless of whether the catalyst or ammonia borane was present (Table 2, entry 8). Therefore, we propose that an iron-hydride complex, potentially generated in situ by the reaction of Fe1 with KO t Bu and H3N·BH3, may serve as the active catalyst for methanolysis. Its presence greatly increased the reaction rate. Based on the above results, our catalytic system effectively facilitated the methanolysis of PET and obtained DMT and EG products with high isolated yields. The Fe1 precatalyst demonstrates high efficiency as a catalyst for PET methanolysis, facilitating the conversion of PET to DMT under mild conditions. The combination of its two catalytic capabilities efficiently hydrogenated and depolymerized PET. 2.3 Polyester degradation through methanolysis/hydrogenative depolymerization The first degradation reaction proceeds in two stages. Initially, employing [Fe(NNHN)Cl2]2 and KO t Bu as catalysts, aromatic polyester plastics such as PET and polybutylene terephthalate (PBT) undergo methanolysis in methanol at 80 °C. This process converts PET into dimethyl terephthalate (DMT) and ethylene glycol (EG), while PBT is transformed into DMT and 1,4-butanediol. In the subsequent step, methanol is completely removed, and the remaining material is redispersed in THF. Transfer hydrogenation then occurs at 60 °C, converting DMT into 1,4-benzenedimethanol, yielding an excellent separation efficiency (Scheme 4 a, methanol is not drawn for clarity, same as below). Through this methanolysis/transfer hydrogenation reaction, PET and PBT can be efficiently hydrogenated and depolymerized to obtain 1,4-benzenedimethanol and methanol. This method effectively addresses plastic pollution, as PET is a wildly produced and most consumed polyester plastic. Most of the water and other beverage bottles used in daily life are made of PET, which is also the most common type of waste plastic discarded by humans. The aliphatic polyester polycaprolactone (PCL) could also be methanolized to produce methyl 6-hydroxyhexanoate with a 90 % isolated yield, which then underwent transfer hydrogenation, producing 1,6-hexanediol with an 87 % isolated yield (Scheme 4b). Chain lipids were less reactive in our catalytic system and required more catalyst (5 mol%) for higher yields. Polylactic acid (PLA) could be converted into methyl 2-hydroxypropanoate and then into 1,2-propanediol with an 89 % isolated yield under the same catalytic conditions (Scheme 4c). Although PCL and PLA are biodegradable plastics that are widely used in daily life and industrial production, their natural degradation conditions are harsh and require prolonged periods, and the degradation products are mainly carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. Therefore, hydrogenative degradation is appropriate for these types of plastics. Polycarbonate plastics, typically those based on bisphenol A (PC), can be hydrogenated directly to bisphenol A and methanol using [Fe(NNHN)Cl2]2 and KO t Bu as the catalytic system (Scheme 4d). In light of the preceding experimental results, the mechanism of the transesterification reaction was elucidated via a deuterated experiment. Specifically, methanol within the reaction system was substituted with deuterated methanol (CD3OD). Subsequent characterization of the products by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy revealed that the resultant product was DMT with complete deuteration of the methyl groups (Scheme 5 ). This observation substantiates that the reaction proceeds via a canonical methanolysis pathway [38]. 2.4 Polyester degradation through hydrogenolysis In the degradation of polyester plastics, methanolysis/hydrogenative depolymerization leads to milder reaction conditions, easier operation, and more convenient mechanism exploration. However, the reaction must be divided into two steps with different solvents, making it unsuitable for practical applications, especially industrial production. Thus, we also attempted direct hydrogenation for plastic degradation and found that the use of hydrogen as the hydrogen source achieved the hydrogenolysis of polyester plastics at high temperature and pressure with [Fe(NNHN)Cl2]2 and KO t Bu as the catalyst system. In this hydrogenolysis experiment, common 0.5-liter PET water bottle was unsealed, cut into pieces, and placed in a 250-mL autoclave. At 120 °C and a 20 bar H2 pressure, diol products with an 84 % isolated yield were obtained at a catalyst loading of 2 mol% Fe1 and 5 mol% KO t Bu (Scheme 6 , top row; Table 3 , entry 1). PCL, a common biodegradable plastic widely used in the medical field, was selected for this experiment, with medical 3D printing supplies serving as the reaction substrates. Under the appropriate reaction conditions, the 3D printing supplies, which were cut into small pieces, were converted into 1,6-hexanediol as a white crystalline solid with a 76 % separation yield at a high catalyst loading of 3 mol% Fe1 and 6 mol% KO t Bu (Scheme 6, second row; Table 3, entry 2). The blue coating on 3D printing supplies was presumably nonreactive and could be easily separated via filtration. A PLA beverage cup was cut into small pieces and placed in the autoclave under the established hydrogenolysis conditions, and 1,2-propanediol was obtained as a light yellow oil with an 87 % isolated yield at a rather low catalyst loading of 1.5 mol% Fe1 and 3 mol% KO t Bu (Scheme 6, third row; Table 3, entry 3). In the subsequent reaction, three CDs were cut into small pieces and added into the reaction system to form bisphenol A and methanol smoothly using 3 mol% Fe1 and 6 mol% KO t Bu (Scheme 6, bottom row; Table 3, entry 4). Due to the thick coating, the separation yield in this reaction was comparatively low at 69 %, and the unreacted coating could also be directly removed via filtration. Relative to our previous Mn-NNN system [19], the present Fe-NNN catalyst achieves slightly lower yields with a markedly cheaper metal source and expanded substrate scope. 3 Conclusion In summary, an NNN-based iron pincer catalyst was developed for the efficient upcycling of polyester and polycarbonate plastics. The catalyst’s ability to facilitate (1) methanolysis and transfer hydrogenation and (2) direct catalytic hydrogenolysis under mild conditions is a breakthrough in plastic waste management. The high yields and broad applicability of the catalyst across various types of plastics (PET, PBT, PCL, PLA, and polycarbonates) underscore its potential for industrial-scale recycling. This research contributes to the academic community by deepening the understanding of catalytic upcycling and offers practical solutions to address the environmental challenges of plastic pollution, aligning with the goals of a circular economy. By converting waste plastics into value-added diols, this study aligns with the circular economy model, promoting a more sustainable future. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient, eco-friendly recycling methods for mitigating the environmental impact of polyester waste remains a significant challenge. Herein, we establish an efficient catalytic system based on an NNN-based iron pincer catalyst, which can facilitate the hydrogenative depolymerization of polyester plastics using two methods. The first method is to depolymerize the polyester into ester monomers via methanolysis and facilitate subsequent transfer hydrogenation using ammonia borane as a hydrogen source to obtain diol products under mild conditions. The second method is to use molecular hydrogen as a hydrogen source for the direct catalytic hydrogenolysis of the plastic to obtain diol products. The catalyst [Fe(NNHN)Cl2] demonstrates high catalytic efficiency in the degradation of polyester and polycarbonate plastics, including when using plastic waste from daily life as raw materials.

coredata.dc:title: Efficient catalytic upcycling of polyester and polycarbonate plastics using an NNN-based iron catalyst
